<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of run_usock:
```c
static void *
run_usock (void *cls)
{
  struct MyData *md = cls;
  struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh = md->urh;
  char buf[128];
  ssize_t got;

  make_blocking (md->sock);
  /* start by sending extra data MHD may have already read, if any */
  if (0 != md->extra_in_size)
  {
    send_all (md->sock,
              md->extra_in,
              md->extra_in_size);
    free (md->extra_in);
  }
  /* now echo in a loop */
  while (1)
  {
    got = recv (md->sock,
                buf,
                sizeof (buf),
                0);
    if (0 >= got)
      break;
    send_all (md->sock,
              buf,
              (size_t) got);
  }
  free (md);
  MHD_upgrade_action (urh,
                      MHD_UPGRADE_ACTION_CLOSE);
  return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function run_usock:
struct MyData
{
  struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh;
  char *extra_in;
  size_t extra_in_size;
  MHD_socket sock;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
send_all (md->sock,
              md->extra_in,
              md->extra_in_size);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: md->extra_in is declared as char * but is used only as a read-only buffer (passed to send_all and then freed) and is not modified in run_usock. According to MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13, the pointer should point to a const-qualified type when possible (e.g. const char *extra_in). Thus, declaring extra_in as char * instead of const char * is a violation. (If other code legitimately modifies the buffer, making it non-const would be necessary and no violation would occur.)
